newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul won ends up on repeated central bank support.
newsitem.headline: Seoul won ends up on repeated central bank support.

text.p: The won closed higher against the dollar on Friday after the Bank of Korea took a strong stance to support the domestic unit, brokers said.
After the central bank intervened repeatedly to prop up the struggling won, the currency closed trading at 843.40. It opened at an intra-day low of 845 and touched a high of 841.80.

"Despite the central bank intervention, expectation of heavy buying by the Office of Supply and import settlements over the next couple of weeks will keep the dollar strong," a European bank dealer said.
Dealers said the office, the government procurement body, bought an estimated $43 million on Friday.
"This buying was seen as evidence that the Office planned large dollar purchases this month, so people are afraid to take short dollar positions," said a local bank dealer.
Traders said the won/dollar rate was expected to move between 840 and 850 next week.
The central bank set Monday's base mid-rate at 842.90, compared to Friday's 842.70.
